title: Tinnitus and CoVID-19
chief_complaint: I have a ringing in my left ear that started immediately after I was diagnosed with COVID-19. I am also very anxious about the lingering effects of the virus, especially my loss of smell.

problem_summary.onset: November 2020, immediately following a positive COVID-19 diagnosis via nasal swab.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Anosmia (loss of smell), significant anxiety regarding long-term health effects of COVID-19.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Severely bothersome; affects many aspects of life (THI 72, TFI 84).

history.present_illness: Patient tested positive for COVID-19 in Nov 2020. Reported anosmia as the only initial symptom. Tinnitus in the left ear began immediately after diagnosis. Patient exhibits significant anxiety regarding the lack of conclusive data on long-term COVID effects.
history.otologic_history: No complaints of hearing loss or other otologic symptoms prior to this. No hearing testing since grade school.
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with COVID-19 (Nov 2020). Significant anxiety observed.
history.prior_management: Completed THI and TFI prior to arrival.

tests.name: Self-Report Scales
tests.key_findings: Scores indicate severely bothersome tinnitus affecting many aspects of life.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild sensorineural hearing loss at 4,000 Hz and above. High-frequency audiometry showed mild-to-moderate loss from 9 kHz through 16 kHz, with no measurable thresholds beyond that.

tests.name: Loudness Tolerance
tests.key_findings: Within normal limits for both speech and pure-tone stimuli.

tests.name: Tinnitus Evaluation
tests.key_findings: Pitch match, loudness match, and minimal masking levels obtained. Residual inhibition testing showed partial inhibition.

numeric_results.Stimulus for RI: White noise for 1 min at 10 dB SL re: MML

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral, mild sensorineural hearing loss at 4,000 Hz and above, extending to a mild-to-moderate loss in the ultra-high frequencies (9â€“16 kHz). Despite the bilateral hearing loss, the tinnitus is reported as unilateral (left-sided). Speech recognition is excellent bilaterally, and loudness tolerance is normal. Self-report measures (THI: 72, TFI: 84) indicate the tinnitus is severely bothersome.
counseling_points: Although you have hearing loss in both ears, your tinnitus is currently only on the left; however, managing the hearing loss can help the tinnitus.
Binaural amplification (hearing aids) is recommended to provide a sound-enriched environment, which often reduces tinnitus perception.
If hearing aids are not an option right now, you can use a smartphone app for sound therapy. Choose a sound like white noise or environmental sounds.
Set the volume of the sound therapy to a 'mixing point' where you can hear both the app sound and your tinnitus comfortably.
Use sound therapy whenever the tinnitus is most bothersome throughout the day.
Consider relaxation techniques, such as Mindfulness Based Tinnitus Stress Reduction (MBTSR), to help manage the distress.
A referral to a mental health professional is recommended to help address the significant anxiety you are experiencing related to your diagnosis.
notes_for_actor: Portray significant anxiety, specifically focused on the unknown long-term effects of COVID-19 and the loss of smell.
You are visibly anxious throughout the testing procedures.
Despite the anxiety, you are a reliable patient during testing.
You have budget constraints that may prevent you from purchasing hearing aids immediately.
